FacilityName: Ashland Hercules Water Technology- Milwaukee Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ASHLAND INC - MILWAUKEE PLANT

RMP EXECUTUVE SUMMARY 

Ashland Inc is dedicated to providing a safe and healthful environment for our employees, customers, and communities.  To do this, we are dedicated to working toward continuous improvement in our operations to prevent pollution, reduce risks, and to enhance safety, health, and environmental performance.  By incorporating these beliefs and attitudes into the way we do things at Hercules, we take a key step forward in minimizing the environmental impact of our operations, satisfying customer needs, and creating shareholder value.  We adhere to the following basic principles in managing our business worldwide:  

- We will comply with the letter and the spirit of all applicable health, safety and environmental laws, regulations, and corporate guidelines.
  
- We will define strategic objectives, develop tactical plans, identify clear accountability, provide necessary resources, and measure our progress on safety, health, and environmental matters on an ongoing basis.  

- Our planning will consider our business goals and significant safety, health and environmental aspects of our products and operations, and will work to reduce adverse impacts. 

- We will provide for an open dialogue on safety, health, and environmental issues relating to our products and our operations with our stakeholders, including shareholders, employees, customers, suppliers, government agencies, and communities.  

- We will work continually to reduce workplace injuries, incidents with the potential to cause property damage, material loss, or interruption of our business, or waste and releases to the environment.  

- All Ashland Inc employees, worldwide, are responsible and accountable for incorporating safety, health, and environmental activities into our daily business activities.  

FACILITY DESCRIPTION:

The primary activity at the Milwaukee Plant is the manufacture of chemical additives used in the pulp and paper industry.  For exampl

e, epichlorohydrin is used in the production of wet-strength resin.  These resins are used in paper towels, napkins, tissues, etc. so that they will not come apart easily when wet.  Epichlorohydrin is a raw material for the process and is consumed in a chemical reaction to make the product.  The plant receives epichlorohydrin in tank trucks and railroad tank cars and stores the material in a storage tank.  The storage tank is provided with a containment dike and leak detectors to minimize adverse impacts from any leaks for spills.  

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM:

The Ashland-Milwaukee facility complies with the OSHA PSM rule.  As a PSM facility, Ashland Inc completes a detailed Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) every 5 years.  The PHA seeks to identify and address potential causes of incidents before they occur.  In addition, PSM training on safe handling of equipment and chemicals is conducted every three years for all Kymene area operators and all maintenance mechanics.  Management of Change (MOC) procedures are followed to ensure that any changes that occur in the Kymene process do not have the potential to result in an increased risk of a safety incident or an accidental release. In addition, routine maintenance is conducted under the facilityA?s preventative maintenance program to ensure that equipment critical to the safe handling of epichlorohydrin is maintained in good condition at all times. System interlocks ensure that incompatible chemicals are never mixed together.  

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

There have been no incidents involving the release of epichlorohydrin in the last 5 years that meet the criteria for inclusion in the 5-year incident history.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

The Milwaukee Plant has a written emergency response plan and coordinates emergency response matters with the local fire department along with the Local Emergency Planning Committee.  The Plant also will be coordinating with the City of Milwaukee Department Neighborhood Services

to ensure all process controls, Mitigation systems, and monitoring devices are in place to ensure safe handling and storage of raw materials.

PLANT IMPROVEMENTS:

The Milwaukee plant recently has replaced scrubber systems on the large and glass reactors to maintain emission control while conserving water resources.

The plant is currently preparing for Responsible Care Management System certification from the ACC.  

Additional lighting has been added around the plant to ensure safety of employees and property.
